(c) whether the Union or any officers or members of the Union have engaged in illegal activities in relation to the election or appointment of officers of the Union or the conduct or purported conduct of the Union's affairs;

(d) if the Union or any officers or members of the Union have engaged in activities of any of the kinds referred to in this or the preceding paragraph, whether the employment conditions applying to the work of ship painters and dockers have contributed to the development of those activities:

What did Mr Costigan discover? He discovered massive tax fraud with union members being made straw directors of shell companies which were asset stripped by the scheme promoter. Mr Howard, of course, was the Treasurer in the late 1970s. He was reluctant to move on taxation avoidance, despite warnings from the Australian Taxation Office. In the end he was forced to do so by the electorate. It now appears that corporate Australia has found a new use for shell companies.

In the early 1980s, companies were stripped to avoid paying tax. In the 1990s, they are being stripped to avoid meeting the legal liabilities to their workers. The man who was so reluctant to move on this issue in the 1970s not only was aware of this new application of an old corporate scam but also explicitly endorsed it. What did Mr Costigan say in his article in the Age on 23 April? He said, amongst other things:
I have followed with despair over the past few months the approach taken by Patrick and the Government . . .
Of special concern in this dispute is the manner in which the union employees of Patrick were deprived of their employment.
He went on later to say:
I am concerned with the restructuring by Patrick of their corporate entities.
He goes on:

In his judgment on Tuesday, Justice North set out in summary form the procedures adopted by Patrick to denude the employing companies of their assets, and to arrange contracts between those companies and the operating Patrick company which contained clauses making it simple to dispense with the services of the union members. The mechanism to achieve this was set up in advance, ready for action.

There is no suggestion that these changes were designed, like the bottom of the harbour schemes, to avoid the payment of tax. However their effect, and inevitably their design, was to avoid obligations under the Workplace Relations Act.
The behaviour of Patrick in relation to its reorganisation of its corporate structure deserves the strongest condemnation.
This is Mr Costigan QC talking; these are not my words. Later he says:
It is almost beyond belief that such endeavours attracted the applause of the Government.
And applause of the government they did attract. He says later:

The events surrounding the late-night sacking of the workers, enforced by security guards and dogs, and the asset stripping of the employing companies, constitute an example of financial, corporate and industrial misbehaviour which is unacceptable in this country.
Then he said:

For my part I am bound to declare that it is offensive to ordinary concepts of decent behaviour. It is the responsibility of the Australian Government to take appropriate steps to make certain it cannot happen again.

It is inevitable, because of its action, that this government stands condemned in relation to this action. Last September Patrick started to reduce the level of capital in its employer businesses and sell assets and shares to other companies in the Patrick group. Up until the third week of September, Patrick Stevedore's companies Nos 1, 2 and 3 employed waterside workers, owned equipment, ran terminals and had contracts with shipping companies. But the business was sold for $300 million to a company further up the corporate chain while assets were sold for $7 million.

The employer companies reduced their capital base by almost $70 million by buying back and then cancelling shares. This soaked up all their cash. Patrick Stevedore's No. 2 paid $24.4 million in buying 609,922 shares at a $1 par value, a $39 premium per share. Patrick Stevedore's No. 1 paid $36.9 million for 45.4 million $1 shares, a 19c discount on par value. Patrick Stevedore's No. 3 paid $6.8 million for 13.5 million shares, a 50 per cent discount on the par value of the $1 shares. I am not aware of any evidence that the terms of section 206 of the Corporations Law were addressed through the appointment of an outside expert opinion to ensure that the share buybacks were fair and reasonable, but I guess we will find out all about that in due course.

When the company assets were sold to another Patrick company, the original employers entered non-exclusive labour supply deals with that company. These labour supply contracts contained automatic termination provisions if the subsidiaries were placed in the hands of administrators. As I said earlier, the contracts could also be terminated if there was industrial action, legal or illegal. In contrast, the P&C contracts signed by Patrick gave the farmers 30 days to rectify a fault with the labour supply once it was identified. The contract could not be terminated if the fault was corrected in that time. That is a remarkable difference.

The Reith plan proved very effective in stripping these companies. At the first meeting of creditors of the four Patrick companies, the creditors were told that they had $400 million in liabilities and just $14 million in assets. The administrator, Mr Peter Brook, said that $150 million was owed in employee entitlements and $250 million to secured creditors, mostly banking syndicates. But this was not a problem for Mr Corrigan. Mr Corrigan said:
As far as we are concerned the companies that are in administration no longer have any rights to supply labour to our facilities and so we won't be proceeding to allow those people entry.
He told the ABC:
We have taken actions which we are confident are completely lawful and completely honest and have no regrets whatsoever, or no concerns whatsoever about them.
On the Face to Face program he was asked:
But my point to you though, is these companies, at the point they sacked those workers, they could not actually fund the redundancies that were due to them, could they?
Mr Corrigan answered:
Most companies can't fund the redundancies if they sack the entire workforce.
Question: But you planned to. That's the difference.
Mr Corrigan then said:
No, we didn't plan to. We negotiated until the very end.
He was then asked:
Exactly how long were you involved in discussions with the government on this issue?
Corrigan then said:

. . . Oh only about 2 weeks before it happened. We went to the Government and said we are getting to the point of complete exasperation. We may need to make people redundant in one form or another. What are the mechanisms through which you might provide redundancy arrangements.

But he then said that the Howard government made mention in December that it was willing to put in place some sort of fund. However, the plan, as we now know, was well in place before that time. So Mr Corrigan thought the plan was legal and appropriate. The government was obviously happy with the plan. After all, it was the mechanism to deliver the minister the scalp of the MUA. Mr Reith was happy to own up to the fact that the government gave Mr Corrigan lots of legal advice. Mr Reith was asked on the AM program on 22 April:
So you did give him that advice?
He was referring to the advice to dismiss their entire work force and replace them quickly in a way that limits ordering reinstatement. Mr Reith said:
We gave both of them quite a lot of legal advice. So sure, we've been very activist.
What have the courts said about this? I want to quote firstly from the summary of the Federal Court's decision of 21 April. On the second page of that decision at point 12, it states:

The cancellation of the labour supply contract and the appointment of administrators on 7 April 1998 were made possible by a complex inter-company transaction which occurred in September 1997. By dividing the functions of employing workers and owning the business between two companies, the Patrick group put in place a structure which made it easier to dismiss the whole workforce. It is arguable, on the evidence, that this was done because the employees were members of the Union. So there is an arguable case that the Patrick employers acted in breach of s298K(1) of the Act.
Point 13 says:
There is also an arguable case that these acts amounted to a breach of the employees' contracts of employment.
I would like to draw the Senate's attention to page 15 of the decision, where it states:

The corporate counsel of Lang Corporation Ltd deposed to the reasons for the restructure, which involved the making of the BPAs and LSAs, the share buybacks and debt repayments. The reasons were to avoid customer confusion, confusion as to which entity owned which assets, to allow better performance monitoring and to allow borrowing at better rates.
I want you to listen to this passage of the judgment:
There is no express denial that a reason for undertaking the restructure in this particular way was to facilitate the termination of the employees' employment.
The court draws the attention of the public to the fact that the Lang Corporation did not deny that was the purpose of the restructuring. The decision goes on:

The reasons given do not explain why clause 13(1)(b) of each LSA took the particular form. Furthermore, the reasons given are not inconsistent with the reason alleged by the applicants. Section 298K(1) requires the prohibited reason to be one reason, but not the only reason.
So the court was very clearly finding against them and in a telling way in that regard. On page 17 of the summary of the decision, it states:

Although Patricks made generalised complaints about the employees' work practices, there is no material which would justify the conclusion at this stage that the workforce was unsatisfactory. Indeed, the company accounts for the year ended 30 September 1996 show that the first respondent made an after tax profit of $10,911,000 for the year ended 30 September 1995 (the first year) and an after tax profit of $20,431,000 for the year ended 30 September 1996 (the second year).

They are very interesting passages from the Federal Court decision. The High Court decision in a number of places is also very interesting to read. On page 5 of the majority decision, the High Court notes of the restructure of the business:
Thus the security of the employer companies' businesses was extremely tenuous. The security of the employees' employment was consequentially altered to their prejudice.
A deliberate tactic. The High Court also highlights on page 6 of the joint decision that:
There is no express denial that a reason for undertaking the restructure in this particular way was to facilitate the termination of the employees' employment.
It also highlights on page 22 that:

. . . in effecting the 1997 reorganisation, the employer companies disposed of their assets including their stevedoring businesses, reduced their issued capital and disposed of a substantial amount of money by the buy-back of their shares and became the mere suppliers of labour, they exposed their continued commercial viability to the discretion of Patrick Operations No 2 (and later to Patrick Operations) in the event of any disruption in the supply of labour.
There are many passages from that decision that I could quote.

Despite the view of Mr Costigan QC, despite the view of Justice North, despite the view of the full bench of the Federal Court and despite the view of the High Court, the Prime Minister continues to back Mr Corrigan to the hilt. In fact, he has said that the events on the waterfront are a defining moment in Australia's industrial relations history. That statement is dead right.

The government all but ignored the Attorney-General's Department when it put this strategy together in this matter. The plan outlined in the 10 March minute was developed by Dr Webster and others, including the law firms Minter Ellison and Dunhill Madden Butler. What was developed was a commercial structure.

I am sure there are a lot of questions being asked in the Attorney-General's Department as I speak about how the government—particularly the minister for workplace relations, the former minister for transport and the Prime Minister himself—could have put itself in such a risky legal position. The government has been caught out because the Attorney-General's Department was left out of this matter. The role of the Attorney-General, and his department, in this fiasco will be revealed and it will make fascinating reading. The extent of the government's legal dilemma is highlighted by the heavy hitters brought in to help it and its alleged fellow conspirators. Patrick has hired Freehills, the NFF has hired Minter Ellison—which were also consultants to the government in relation to waterfront reform; and some very interesting questions were asked at estimates which have not yet been answered in relation to that conflict—the administrators are being represented by Phillips Fox and the government has hired Dunhill Madden Butler.

The key point in this whole waterfront fiasco was the endorsement of the strategy provided to the minister for workplace relations on 27 February last year. That paper was the basis for the actions taken by the government and Patrick around Australia at 11 p.m. on 7 April. I have advised the Senate on a previous occasion that the waterfront paper was initially prepared by Mr Derryn Gillespie and Dr Greg Feeney when the maritime transport division was located in the Department of Transport and Regional Development. However, the paper was rewritten by Mr Gillespie with no reference back to his colleagues. I assume it was provided to Mr Reith's office in draft form and was rewritten accordingly. Mr Gillespie refocused the paper on the confrontationist option and that led to the sacking of the work force on 7 April.

According to the now famous 10 March minute from Mr Gillespie to Mr Reith, it was intended that the 27 February paper provide the basis for a meeting with the Prime Minister. I am advised that the strategy outlined in the paper—sack the entire work force to get the MUA—was presented to the Prime Minister before Dr Webster's consultancy commenced, and he explicitly endorsed the plan. The Prime Minister was also kept up-to-date on the progress of the plan as it was fleshed out by Dr Webster, the National Farmers Federation and Patrick's. What this government now confronts is an economic and political disaster of its own making. It set about building a plan to destroy a union. It is going to fail, and it is going to get into a lot of trouble over it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The government rejects the general business motion which is listed under Senator Faulkner's name. The first thing I note is that Senator Faulkner was not here to move his own motion. Instead, it was moved by Senator O'Brien, who brought nothing new to this long, drawn-out saga on the waterfront—and there is more to come. Senator O'Brien attempted to construct what we have heard before, but in some sort of new smoke and mirror fashion—that what Patrick's has undertaken is illegal and that the courts have found it to be illegal. Well, they have not. They have not found the restructuring by Patrick's to be at all illegal. A prima facie case has been established and the main case is still to be undertaken.

speech.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The motion that is before the Senate is based on the false premise that Patrick's hire companies are illegal entities; they are not. They were found by the High Court not to be illegal; rather, they were found to be legitimate entities that are entitled to undertake commercial activities and make commercial decisions. We await, Senator Carr, some of those commercial decisions and realities which the administrators are now pondering over. It is important to say that because the government would not be supporting any company for any reason if they undertook their affairs illegally. We on this side of the House do not believe that the end justifies the means.
—That's what you're into.

—But you do, by your defence of the MUA, the indefensible. Did anyone notice that Senator O'Brien did not once mention the reforms that are so necessary down on the waterfront? His defence of the MUA really was a case of the means justifying the end. The end, for those on the other side of the House, is that the MUA stay in their established form as the most powerful union within the trade union movement, as the supplier of funds and the propper-upper of the Labor Party, and all their rorts and extortions down on the waterfront continue beyond the year 2000 into the next century.

speech.para: The truth is that the motion before the Senate is an exercise in defending the indefensible. It is yet another strident defence of the MUA by the Labor Party because, as I said, the MUA pays the bulk of the bills of the Labor Party. It dominates the union movement. The MUA leaders are notorious rorters and extortionists. This dates way back to the fathers of the union—way back to the Second World War, when they held our waterfront to ransom through shocking behaviour, when our fighting troops were denied supplies and arms. It was utterly against the national interest. This is what happened way back in the 1940s. Those fathers of the union have not changed at all. The MUA—under another name; that is all—is behaving in the same way.

This is not a union representing the working class or the battlers of Australia; I wish it was. For example, a crane driver, for 14 hours work a week, can be paid over $90,000. This is a practice which adds costs to our exports and to our imports. They are sacrificing the jobs of other workers. This has a cascading effect through all industries throughout Australia.

While all this vitriol is being heaped upon Patrick's throughout this dispute, the most interesting development in the last couple of days has been the entry of P&O into this debate. They are now demanding fundamental reforms which are no different from Patrick's. For months now, the Labor Party have been demonising Patrick's, saying, `Why can't Patrick's be like P&O?' How ironic! Like Patrick's, P&O are now demanding reforms on the waterfront, because their workplace agreements are only now falling due. P&O were just biding their time. Don't think P&O are on your side; they are more like Patrick's than Patrick's are like them.

As the realities of the marketplace hit home to those opposite and to the MUA, and as the debate drags on, the government's determination is proven. In the coming weeks the MUA have two choices: to reform their work practices and change the culture down on the waterfront, or leave. Those are their two choices. They will take the latter, you wait and see. Should they be foolish enough to take the latter, there are others willing to take up the jobs that they will walk out on, such as the NFF-run P&C Stevedores. However, we will wait and see how the MUA deal with the market realities that they face in the coming weeks.

One obvious factor throughout this whole waterfront dispute has been the importance which the MUA have placed on public relations. We have all noticed it—the gloss over and above the substance. With regard to winning media opinion, they have certainly done that to a great extent—none more so than the ABC. They have won the ABC over to their side, there is no doubt about that, but that is never hard to do.

John Coombs has been so conscious of reshaping his public image that he has called in Jane Singleton on a daily basis to get advice, to whack on the make-up, to know what to say and how to dress up. Jane Singleton is reshaping John Coombs. The tough, rough nut from the waterfront is now looking just a little more decent before the cameras. He is all done up by the public relations people. So the usual grand gesture of the deluders is now occurring. They have been on their way to the picket lines to support their brothers in arms in the MUA.

These self-deluders have made ridiculous comparisons of the MUA to Poland's Solidarity movement and South Africa's union movement against apartheid. Only last night in this chamber, Senator Forshaw was idealising the MUA, making comparisons with the Polish struggle against communism or the union struggles—and good struggles they were—against apartheid in South Africa. The truth of the matter is John Coombs is no Lech Walesa, no matter how the public relations departments dress him up. He is more like an Arthur Scargill, who, if you remember, was paid by the Russian communists at the time he brought England to its knees when he carried out his strikes.

Sure as can be, the MUA is no Solidarity, nor is their cause. They do not represent the Aussie battlers, particularly on their hourly rates. Was the union movement so strident—the ACTU and their political allies across there—when the timber workers lost their jobs against the ridiculous ambit claims by the green movements? When the Ravenshoe workers lost their jobs up in Queensland several years ago, was the union movement defending their jobs? They were battlers, they were working class, they were driven from their jobs: where were you?

But you were all out on the platforms and the pickets with the MUA, the money men of the union. Best estimates are they have $20 million cash in their bank account. They are going to need it for all their legal fees. That is why you succumb to the MUA's call and not to the call of the battlers and the real workers from Ravenshoe when they were driven out of their jobs. They are the working-class people who deserve a strong and decent union and a strong political arm. The point is, the general public are not fooled by this; you are fooled, you are self-deluders, the general public are not.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —We are willing to go to an election on that, Senator Carr, if you so wish. I would have thought, for all the expenses the union is paying for public relations that the public relations department would not have made such a huge error, at least in Victoria, when they wheeled out Joan Kirner and Bill Kelty to have their pictures taken on the picket lines. For all Victorians, this brings back memories of the worst possible face of the union. Isn't Joan Kirner best remembered as the Premier who drove the state into its gloomiest and darkest period, its most depressing period, all because she was then a captive of John Halfpenny's Trades Hall Council? And isn't Bill Kelty best known and remembered for his `blood in the streets' comments during the last election? On both occasions, it cost you votes and it cost you a public image before the people of Victoria. It cost you elections, but you still wheel out the two of them. I invite you to keep wheeling them out before the cameras and in the newspapers, and have them on the picket lines. It only proves the point that these people are the friends of the MUA, that these people are self-deluding. They think they have some idealistic fight here when it is nothing of the sort; they are holding the nation to ransom.
—There is certainly no idealism about you!

—Senator Carr, you may be interested to know that I can give a very honest real-life account of the tactics of the MUA. For all those who think that John Coombs is Lech Walesa and that MUA is Solidarity, for all those who have deluded themselves that that is what this is all about, let me give you some real-life accounts of the picket lines down on the docks. I have several friends working for P&C Stevedores, the NFF-run stevedoring company. They tell me what happens down there, how they are intimidated and how efficient they are for such inexperienced workers.

speech.para: Senator Carr, you were seen down on Swanson Dock having your picture taken with the picketers. How could I leave out Senator Carr when I talk about Joan Kirner and Bill Kelty? You were with them Senator Carr. You keep linking arms with them and putting yourself on the front page of the Herald Sun, the Australian and the Age because it only does our cause good! Down on Swanson Dock picket lines—and I use this personal story because I know Senator Forshaw last night tried to bring out a personal story, and where there is one story from one side of the fence, there is always another one—there were death threats and physical threats upon the workers of P&C Stevedores when they went to work for Patrick. And probably worse, the young women who were working for P&C Stevedores were physically threatened in a vile manner.

talk.start.para: —What a load of drivel.
—Senator Carr, do you really think it is not true? Don't let this one get past you because you know it is true. You know how they behave on those picket lines.

talker.name: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Jacinta Collins)

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator McGauran! Through the chair, please.

—Madam Deputy President, the thrust of this whole debate really should be about reform. That is something Senator O'Brien never talked about. Yet that is the substance of this debate. That is looking beyond the public relations exercise by the union and the union know that the reform that is going to occur is just a matter of time. A great deal has been said in regard to what reform can be achieved on the waterfront and in the past few weeks we have seen the publication of the Productivity Commission handed down. It is a damning document for just how inefficient our ports have been. You can add the Productivity Commission's report to the pile of other documents about the inefficiencies of the waterfront—several of them were produced by the Labor government.

speech.para: Given the Asian economic crisis, it is now imperative that this government moves to reform our waterfront. Time has run out for Australia and, therefore, time has run out for the MUA. To this end, the government has recently published seven benchmarks which it seeks to achieve. The first one is overmanning. Quite frankly, even the MUA's leader John Coombs concedes that there is definitely an overmanning problem down on the waterfront. Improved productivity: that is a very general term, but we can bring it down to the benchmark of crane rates. Australia's average is some 18 container lifts per hour and we are seeking a benchmark of 25, which we believe is achievable.

I shall give an example as a measure of what 18 means and how inefficient 18 container lifts per hour is. I have just returned from parts of southern Africa where I was part of a political delegation. We visited Mozambique—a war-torn country for more than 25 years which has just made peace. It is now in the infancy of its democracy. The main capital—Maputo—was basically boarded up just four years and the port has just be come operational again over the last couple of years.

P&O Australia have bought the management rights for this port and own some 30 per cent of it. It intends it to be a major container port for the southern African region. Their equipment is antiquated, their docks are basically bombed out, and their workers are incredibly inexperienced. They have really only been going for the last couple of years.

To P&O Australia's credit, they see a future in this area. They are lifting 16 containers per hour with antiquated equipment and with inexperienced workers. They have told us that within 12 months, once they get these workers up and running an operation, they will surpass Australia's 18. There is a benchmark that we cannot even match in a bombed out country that has been war-torn for the past 25 years. They have a great deal of hope in that country and it would be a disgrace to see Australia surpassed by the efforts of P&O in Mozambique. So overmanning is the problem.

The third problem is greater reliability. Australian ports have the worst strike rate in the world. The level of industrial action on the waterfront in 1996 was 1,250 working days lost per thousand employees. Just as a measure, compare that with the rest of the Australian economy. Against 1,250 working days lost per thousand employees, only 135 working days were lost per thousand employees in all other industries. This is a ratio of 10:1 compared with other industries in Australia. As two per cent of the world's shipping trade is in Australia, the waterfront has the highest level of industrial unrest in the world—23 per cent of working days lost on the waterfront across the world. We are the worst strikers in the world: little wonder that is a benchmark.

Occupational health and safety is the fourth of the seven benchmarks the government is attempting to achieve. The fifth is lower stevedoring costs. Of course, with greater stevedoring competition—like the NFF's P&C—lower costs will be established by market pressure. The sixth benchmark relates to making the best use of new technologies, which will require a massive capital injection by the existing and new stevedores. And of course, training is the seventh item.

talk.start.para: —Where were the registered trainers down on the wharves? Jeff Kennett was dead right about you!

—I can tell you, Senator Carr, about this idea that the wharfies—the MUA—have some monopoly on understanding of all the technical equipment and the strapping of the ships and the shifting of the containers, et cetera. I know some of the NFF P&C non-unionised workers have got the job down pat within a matter of months of training. Experience will make them better, but this is no complicated job and it can be done better. They have proven it, particularly some of the young women who are driving the big cranes. They have greater concentration and greater work effort than many of the MUA workers. Not all the MUA workers are to blame—it is the leadership and the thuggery clique that they have around them. Madam Acting Deputy President, we reject this motion.
—I wish to introduce a less adversarial note in this matter. What this motion is about—
—You should have thought about that in the industrial relations act.

—Regardless of the foolish intrusion of Senator Carr, who forgets that it is the Workplace Relations Act which the MUA and others who have been wronged in this issue are relying on, the issue I wish to address here is the question of what is right. Regardless of who is involved in a particular issue, the very concept of allowing employers or anyone with a contractual obligation to escape those obligations—to employees or to any other creditor—through corporate restructuring is an extremely dangerous and evil concept. For any government of the day to even hint at—and this government did not hint; it was forthright about it—support for any corporate asset strippers, is a serious misjudgment. The outcry from those of all political persuasions against this assault on our moral and legal values has surprised many of those who thought that bashing wharfies was an easy way to get electoral support.

speech.para: The fact is that if corporations are allowed to set up subsidiaries, are allowed to withdraw their assets and their financing and then to declare them bankrupt so that they can avoid their contractual obligations, then we are all at risk. It is not just employees; it is creditors, bankers—their contracts could be affected by such restructuring, landlords. tenants, the small business people whom Minister Reith recently put a fair trading act through to protect, and it is any supplier. When this restructuring device was activated by the Patrick group, a shiver of fear went through numerous people who realised that their contractual obligations could be avoided by the same device.

This is not a new issue. It has been raised before in the bottom-of-the-harbour days, and it was raised and covered in 1988 by the Law Reform Commission when it conducted a general insolvency inquiry. As a part of that inquiry the commission considered the possibility of making related companies liable for the debts of an insolvent company in certain circumstances, and the commission recommended that companies should be so liable. Because of that advice which was given to the Labor government of the day by the Law Reform Commission, the Australian Democrats have constructed an amendment to the Corporations Law which is to be debated in the next session. The amendment will seek to prevent corporate groups from stripping assets from insolvent companies to prevent payments to employees or to any other creditors. We hope that we will get the support of the Senate to end the practice, but I think the point made by Senator O'Brien is that this is a little late; it is bolting the stable door too late—the horse is gone. We have to hope that the courts will regard this means of avoiding obligations to employees as not only improper, not only immoral, but hopefully they will regard it as illegal.

The Australian Democrats have clearly put on the record their dislike of any system which applauds the wholesale sacking of 1,400 workers because they belong to a union. It does not matter whether they belong to the MUA, a communist union, a farmers union or any other kind of union; it is wrong to sack workers because they belong to a union. It is just as wrong to avoid the obligations you are required to have as an employer by structuring or restructuring your assets and your companies in such a way that employee entitlements cannot be paid. It has not missed the attention of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), of other ministers and of the Senate that that same device has recently been used on the workers of Cobar and Woodlawn and has affected them. Pretty soon, we will all have tenants or suppliers or banks or somebody else who is a creditor knocking on our doors and squealing about this. Over and above the adversarial politics of who loves and who hates what, we must pay attention to the very real dangers identified in this motion that corporate asset stripping poses for anyone who has a contractual obligation and who can avoid it by what I regard as shonky, sneaky, improper actions using a device to be abhorred.

We hope that the amendment we are putting up will make this practice exceptionally difficult in future. I am aware that the Labor Party have further amendments, and I would hope that the government would move to support them. If the government's intention was to reform the waterfront, to damage their own case so savagely by even pretending or starting to support any kind of activity which smacks of such immorality is a very silly thing to have done because, as a result of it, large sections of the community have been turned against the very objective they were trying to achieve.

I do not have much more to say on this issue. I think the Senate should condemn the government for condoning the practice of asset stripping. They should not confuse the objective of improving productivity on the wharves—an objective supported by the Labor Party, the Democrats, the coalition, the MUA and the employers; we differ over the means, not the objective—with allowing companies to behave in a manner which avoids their contractual responsibilities and obligations and puts families at risk. Next time it could be the families of farmers, next time it could be the families of retail tenants or the families of some supplier. It is just not the proper behaviour for government to agree with. I was deeply distressed and ashamed that ministers of the crown could have supported and applauded such behaviour. Accordingly, I indicate that the Democrats will support the motion moved by the opposition.

talk.start.para: —I commend Senator Murray, my Western Australian Democrat colleague, on the content of the speech that he has just made to the Senate. I make the point right at the beginning that he did at least address the text of the motion that is before the chamber, unlike the speaker prior to him, Senator McGauran from the National Party of Victoria, who completely and utterly evaded the text of the motion. Senator McGauran embarked rather on an attack on the Maritime Union of Australia, the trade union movement in general and the Labor Party as well—all lumped in together.

speech.para: To help people who might want to understand what this debate is about, I repeat for the record the text of the notice of motion by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Faulkner) and moved and spoken to so admirably by my colleague Senator O'Brien earlier this afternoon. The motion reads:

That the Senate condemns the Government for condoning the practice of asset-stripping companies in order to evade the normal contractual responsibilities of employers to their employees, as evidenced by Government support for the corporate re-structuring and asset-stripping of Patrick Stevedores' labour hire companies.

I am tempted to seek to amend the motion to not only delete the word `condoning' but also insert the words `the government jumping into bed with the various individuals who have operated around Patrick Stevedores'. It is becoming more and more evident day by day as further evidence is brought to the attention of the public that senior figures—senior ministers in this government, senior figures in ministers offices and senior identities in a number of government departments—have been up to their necks in the conspiracy to destroy the Maritime Union of Australia, and they have done it by the foulest means possible. They have done it by illegal means and they seek to cover their tracks. The law, it seems, is actually bigger than even senior figures in this government, as three very recent decisions of the courts have upheld. I refer to two decisions—one in the full court of the Federal Court and a later decision of the High Court of Australia.

This whole debacle began in February 1996 when the then opposition spokesperson on transport promised that a coalition government would, if elected, break the grip of the Maritime Union of Australia. Mr Sharp said that in 1996. It would seem the government has held to that promise since it has been elected. As a result, we have seen major disruption in various ports throughout Australia, in ports where there has been no industrial disputation for a large number of years. Yet the individuals employed were sacked merely because they were members of the Maritime Union of Australia.

Who were the major players in the game? There have been many and some have been named by my colleague Senator O'Brien and other speakers today. The main character in all of this, I would suggest, was Mr Chris Corrigan. Mr Corrigan now needs no introduction to the people of Australia. He certainly needs no introduction to corporate Australia and the trade union movement in Australia. His actions, since he took over Patrick Stevedores, have had one main objective—not necessarily to make a profit for his organisation, which essentially should be what he was appointed to do—which is to break a trade union.

The game has not been fully played out yet. Perhaps at the end it will be Mr Corrigan who is broken. Already Mr Corrigan has, out of his own mouth, been exposed to be a liar of the highest order. He misled, deceived and lied openly in order to advance his objective about breaking a union and sacking the employees of his company. All of this is on the public record. Unfortunately, it is not on the public record in the detail that would allow every individual in our society to understand the type of character Mr Corrigan is and the types of people that he is dealing with.

I want to use the time of the Senate this afternoon, when speaking about this asset-stripping exercise, to read into the record the transcript of a meeting that occurred between Mr Corrigan, Mr Michael Wells and Mr Peter Kilfoyle. Mr Wells and Mr Kilfoyle were the operators of a company called Fynwest. Fynwest achieved notoriety for the fact that it organised, hired and arranged for a number of Australians to be recruited to its company before moving to the port of Dubai in the Middle East to be trained as waterside workers. The meeting that I refer to occurred on 31 January this year, after the Dubai exercise had been exposed. I quote in part:

Corrigan . . . I have to have credibility. If I tell a blatant lie and I really know what the answer is, and down the track something emerges, then my credibility is shot and then the next phases won't work.
Wells But you have already said you weren't involved.

Corrigan Mmm, I've hedged around and in more recent times I've hedged deliberately so in fact there's a trail now that says I've been equivocal. That might sound subtly different but it is actual important in the sphere. I'm not protecting myself, I'm protecting the overall scheme. But in the end game it may be that I have some credibility anyway, so I can't just come out and totally deny it. So it may be, depending on how it emerges, it may be that I have to `fess up. If I `fess up, I certainly am going to say that I did not know these people were serving military people, and I most certainly would say that I wouldn't have done it that way had I known.
Kilfoyle That what annoys me with Dubai, I know you don't agree with me, but there was no—
I am not sure about this next word; I do not know whether I should say it or not. It is somewhat of a profanity which refers to a particular part of the male anatomy—

saying look here is the document, this is a legal thing that we are doing. We needed a . . . from Fynwest, nothing more. To get up and say, hey, this is all legal, here is the letter from the CO, here's the clause from the army saying they can bloody do it . . .

Corrigan It would only work if the person releasing the press statement is credible. The structure we had in place was fatal from the beginning because Fynwest or whomever could have come out with a press statement, but the facts of the matter are that Fynwest couldn't say where the money was coming from, couldn't say who the principal was, and at the end of the day, I have to remind you, you contradicted your colleague here on day one about where they were going to work. The credibility of Fynwest from day one was chopped to pieces and so you could have come out with all the statements that you liked, but the press wouldn't have had a bloody penny of it.
Kilfoyle That's because there was no credible person, as far as a press person to bloody handle it. If that would have happened and we had another week Dubai, we would have had these guys right.

Corrigan I know that. We made that mistake and at the end of the day it was structurally a disaster. Remember why we made the mistake, because we thought we were able to keep it a secret. And we didn't. If we thought it through clearly enough, we would have said to ourselves, we'd never keep this a secret, we've got to . . . the structure that allows us to be credible.

I am actually quoting verbatim from those statements, and if the grammar is not correct, it is not necessarily my fault. This is an intriguing document in relation to this meeting of people who, at this particular point in time, were bedfellows in breaching the law and attacking the working people of this country through the MUA. They were acting as agents for the federal government at this particular point in time.

Since the meeting on 31 January, they have indeed fallen out, and Mr Wells has gone public with his declarations that were published in the Age newspaper a couple of days ago. So what we have here is actually what occurred prior to the falling out. Corrigan is an interesting character, and there are some more quotable quotes from this meeting that will serve the record well. I quote again from the transcript:

Corrigan From a political point of view everybody needs this to go away. It's be come politically bad news. Now I agree with you, it's not right, but it doesn't matter whether it's right or wrong. You only have to read the press, they constantly want to link these things up and get Patricks in the middle of it say. Patricks is the common thread through here. What they're trying to do is to link everything up into this giant conspiracy leading up to Government. What they want to do is link the whole shooting match up, now there's nothing wrong with this, in PR terms yet. There's nothing wrong with this in PR terms and there are some queries about our relationship with the Union, but leave that aside.

Now at this stage these people are okay, (Dubai trainees) they've got to be kept clean. If we are going to work it somehow we've got to work it, somehow we've got to get rid of this as best as possible. Obviously, we don't want to get rid of these people. We've got the people here employed. I believe the only way, we've got to get rid of that this is for you have to step out of the loop.

`You' to step out of the loop being Mr Wells and Mr Kilfoyle, their bed partners. It is interesting to read what they think of their own loyal work force—the people that they brought over to Dubai. Although it may have been their work force, it has been proven since that in fact some of these people who went to Dubai were actually serving in Australia's armed forces at that particular point in time and should not have been going to Dubai in any case.

talk.start.para: —I suppose the minister didn't know anything about that either.

—He probably did not. But that is what I said in my opening remarks, Senator Carr: that the conspiracy reaches the highest political office in this land, and it also reaches the offices of many of the senior ministers in the current government. They certainly knew about it.

speech.para: Let me go on to talk about what these people thought about their own loyal work force—these thugs they had hired at that time; these people who later appeared masked in balaclavas with dogs to protect them when they were encouraged by the government to take over the waterfront on 7 April of this year. The transcript goes on:

Corrigan In order to get this to work. So what I'm proposing is that in ordering these people free to apply for jobs here, what we have to do is tell these people that we are giving them notice. So Fynwest tell these people this thing's been a disaster, not a disaster—unable to complete the training. I'll draft a letter.
Wells No letter, must be face to face.—
a commendable attitude, one would think—

Corrigan Unable to complete the training and give them two months notice and we direct them in a very, in as subtle a way as possible over here. Now the problem is, if you ring all of these blokes up and tell them `Look, go and apply for a job here' or more to the point, I guess you could ring them up and say `Why don't you apply for a job over here'. But if you ring them up and tell them `You will get a job' and one of these blokes goes to the press and says `I've been told I will get a job', finished. What these blokes are saying `Look if you can deliver. . .—
I have to be careful with this because this guy uses a few profanities from time to time—
Kilfoyle They don't really want us, I know that. My intelligence is telling me now. From people in there, they don't—
want a bar of us. I know that. I know that from my own intelligence. But, for them to get this off the ground they've got 76 problems, problem children.

Corrigan I don't look at it like that. At the end of the day that's not the point. These people, we owe these people a chance to have a go. That is the way I look at it. That is the facts. They are not problems, they are opportunities. What we've got to do is work out how to minimize the problem to give these blokes a fair go. Okay.
Kilfoyle May I say . . .

Corrigan The only way to do that, the only way to do that, is to close this off and somehow to give these people the hint that they will be given a good hearing over here. Which they will be, I can assure.
Kilfoyle What do you call a good hearing Chris? The records stand as they are.
Corrigan They are going to get jobs, but you can't tell them that.
Kilfoyle I realise that. Okay that's all I wanted to know.

Corrigan I'm going to go out of here tomorrow, we reach an agreement today. I'm going to go over there with all the list. I'm going to the bloody Farmers and say to them these blokes will get jobs, everyone of them that we give them. Now if they interview some bloke and he is absolutely unacceptable, I can't deliver totally. But I can assure you, they will get fixed. But we can't tell them that! If one of these blokes, that we haven't yet identified is the leak, gets on the bloody radio or goes to Coombs or whoever and says `I've been told if I go here I will get a job', then none of them will get jobs. The minute this thing arises, the minute this thing arises, the Farmers are going to say `We want nothing to do with them' because they can't afford to. It has to be very delicately handled.

It seems that Mr Corrigan in his wisdom at that particular point in time was, despite what he said earlier, worried about the press reaction to what they were doing. They were worried about their own people—the mercenaries they had recruited to send to Dubai to train as waterside workers. They were worried that these loyal individuals that they had recruited to take the jobs of other Australians were worried about what was going to happen to them when they fronted up to the National Farmers Federation front company that was going to take jobs on the waterfront.

talk.start.para: —The courts were what they should have really been worried about.

—They were worried about the courts, but they were also obviously worried about the public relations at that particular point in time. Now the government is the one that is worried about public reaction to this. The Australian public has not accepted the right of the government, the National Farmers Federation or any company to go in in the dead of night and take the jobs of workers using thugs disguised in balaclavas, carrying weapons and using dogs. That action has backfired on the government. Public opinion is telling them so.

speech.para: It may be that certain sections of the public are not as friendly to waterside workers or MUA workers as some of us are. I do not have a problem with saying that I have been down to the picket lines and stood by my colleagues, representatives of the workers. Some people do not know the full story of what happens on the waterfront. They do not know about the dangers or the levels of incomes of those people. Some people have swallowed—hook, line and sinker—the propaganda that was put out, particularly by Minister Reith, about the earning power of waterside workers. However, they are learning.

Whatever they feel about waterside workers, they are not going to stand for the terrorist type activities that were engaged in with the complicity of ministers of the Crown. They are not going to stand for those tactics. They condemn them, and they are quite proper in condemning them. In condemning the government, they are condemning Mr Corrigan and his ilk for what they, in turn, have done on the waterfronts of Australia. The actions that we have seen in the last six or eight months in particular, starting with Cairns and continuing through to Dubai and then to all the ports of Australia, are un-Australian activities and they are condemned.

talk.start.para: —Nothing underlines the fact that this resolution on asset-stripping of companies, which has been put forward today by the Labor opposition, has no substance whatsoever than the remarks we have just heard from Senator McKiernan. This motion seeks to condemn the government for allegedly condoning the practice of asset-stripping of companies in relation to Patrick Stevedores' labour hire companies and the current efforts to reform the waterfront.

speech.para: Senator McKiernan had the gall to stand up and condemn Senator McGauran for not addressing that resolution relating to asset-stripping, and yet we have just heard from Senator McKiernan for 20 minutes and he has also completely ignored this resolution—having just condemned Senator McGauran out of hand for not speaking about the details of the resolution. Senator McKiernan commented on the Federal Court and the High Court cases and then he gave a long and very boring reading of alleged transcripts of con versations of people supposedly involved in waterfront reform.

Senator McKiernan said at the outset that the actions of those seeking waterfront reform had been illegal and had been declared illegal by the courts. That is not true. In its final decision on the appeal from the Federal Court, the High Court reinforced the role of the administrators in the management of Patrick Stevedores' labour hire companies. After the decision was handed down by the High Court, the MUA trumpeted victory in its court action against Patrick's, but it was no such thing. It was not a victory—and if it was, it was certainly a pyrrhic victory because the High Court declared very clearly that the future of Patrick's was to be left in the hands of the administrators and that they had the ultimate decision as to whether or not the MUA members would be re-employed.

Senator McKiernan went on to quote at great length from alleged transcripts of meetings, essentially regarding the Dubai training exercise. At one stage I heard him refer to alleged comments that said that the matters needed to be delicately handled. He said that that was evidence of a conspiracy and, perhaps, of a public relations problem. Again, it is evidence of no such thing. It is evidence of the history of thuggery and intimidation on the waterfront which has been engaged in by the MUA. Obviously, to avoid that intimidation and thuggery, matters have to be dealt with with a measure of experience and delicate handling—especially if the history of thuggery and intimidation from the MUA was not to succeed in this particular situation. That is what the reference was to.

Let me come back to this motion which alleges that the government is condoning asset-stripping in relation to Patrick Stevedores. Where is the evidence that the government has condoned that alleged asset-stripping? No evidence whatsoever has been presented by either of the two Labor Party senators that we have heard speak in support of this motion today.

The only illegality that we have so far experienced in this matter is the illegality perpetrated by the Maritime Union of Australia itself, because in the Victorian Supreme Court today Justice Beach has declared just that illegality. He has found the MUA to be in breach of his order regarding picketing and to be in contempt of court. The only illegality in relation to this matter has been declared in the Victorian Supreme Court today. Let that be an end to any claims of illegality from those opposite.

The Labor Party is locked into this illegal behaviour, because the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) himself has given support to these illegal pickets on the waterfront. Another senior Labor spokesman, Simon Crean, when asked while on the picket himself why he was breaking the law, replied, `No, I don't believe I'm breaking the law at all.' The Victorian Supreme Court has found today that they were breaking the law, and he was a participant in that—quite obviously—on that occasion.

We have the Labor Party continuing to support union heavies like Greg Combet who said, `Bad laws should not be respected.' I seem to remember a bloke called Don Dunstan who used to have that attitude too, and we know how South Australia finished up as a result of his years of maladministration. In relation to the Supreme Court, Dean Migehll said to `totally and absolutely ignore it' and Jennie George of the ACTU said something similar—that she would simply ignore the Supreme Court. John Coombs, the doyen of the MUA, says, `We cannot take legal action, so we'll take a bit of illegal industrial action.' There is where the attitude to the law on the part of the trade unions stands very clear in this dispute. They have no respect for the law whatsoever. Yet we find the Labor opposition coming in here, seeking to condemn the government and seeking to condemn Patrick's because of some `as yet to be proven' allegations of asset-stripping and the government allegedly condoning such activity.

The reality of this issue is that the MUA set out to break Patrick's, because Patrick's had the intestinal fortitude to stand up and say, `Enough is enough. The waterfront needs reform.' Enough certainly was enough for Patrick's, because it had lost $56 million due to the behaviour of the MUA over an extend ed period of time. No wonder Patrick's stood up and said, `It is time we had some proper reform on the waterfront.' The industrial warfare in which the MUA has engaged has cost Patrick's $56 million and has sent it broke. That is what cost the wharfies their jobs when they were necessarily retrenched by the labour hire companies operating under Patrick's.

When people are retrenched, no-one wants to see people lose what entitlements they might legally have. The government is certainly willing to look at areas that might strengthen the rights of employees in a situation where there is illegal activity undertaken. But no illegal activity has been found in this matter.

In calling on the Senate to act on this issue today, both Senator Faulkner and Senator O'Brien—Senator Faulkner gave notice of the motion and sent Senator O'Brien in to do his dirty work for him—are actually asking the Senate to condemn their own laws. These are laws that were put in place by the previous Labor government. The Corporations Law, as it stands in relation to this matter, is not a law of the Liberal-National party government; it is a law that was put in place by the previous government and that has been there for 13 years without any changes. So if there is any substance in this matter, let us sheet home the blame to where it belongs, and that is to the previous Labor government—not the present government at all.

The proposals to make some changes to this law as a result of this issue are designed to protect employee entitlements. But it needs to be remembered that this issue crosses boundaries between the Corporations Law, industrial law and policies. It is a complex issue when an employer is insolvent. Attempting to protect employee entitlements in that situation is not something that can be fixed with a snap of the fingers as the opposition seem to be suggesting. The fact is there are already widespread provisions within the Corporations Law to protect employees in these circumstances.
Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The other thing that needs to be remembered is that there are some one million corporations in Australia which would be affected by changes to the Corporations Law. It is very important that we do not have any unforeseen and undesirable consequences as a result of changes to the Corporations Law.

speech.para: Senator Conroy has been interjecting here in the last few minutes. He is a member of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities which I chair. He would know only too well the very detailed process that has been gone through on the current areas of the Corporations Law that are being reformed through the CLERP. A lot of study has been done on the need for change and on the areas that require change. Draft legislation has been published, comments have been sought on the draft legislation and now we finally have bills before our committee for consideration. To have a knee-jerk reaction because some alleged issue has arisen—to immediately advocate some changes to the Corporations Law without at all examining what the unintended consequences of those changes might be for companies not in any way involved in the situation that is extant—would be very unwise indeed.

The other thing that needs to be remembered is that the Corporations Law is a cooperative scheme that relies on the cooperation of state and territory governments, and changes to the Corporations Law have to be processed through the Ministerial Council for Corporations. It would be quite without precedent for the federal government to support any amendments to the Corporations Law which firstly have not been examined by that Ministerial Council.

The government has, however, taken steps to examine the issue. At a recent meeting of state and territory ministers for labour, the Departments of Labour Advisory Committee has been asked to undertake a detailed examination of the matter, including consultation with all affected parties. The Departments of Labour Advisory Committee is going to report to the next meeting of the council of labour ministers. The government has responded to this issue but it is doing so in a proper and considered way in order to examine all of the issues, see if any necessary reforms are needed and determine the process that needs to be undertaken for those reforms.

Let us not have any suggestion—as we have in this motion today—that the government is condoning any alleged improper activity on the part of a corporation to deny its employees their entitlements. That is simply a red herring that the opposition seeks to draw across the real issue, which is the continued intransigence of the Maritime Union of Australia to accede to any waterfront reform. This reform becomes more urgent as every day goes by.

The reason the Labor Party want to avoid focusing on this issue is that they completely failed in their limited attempts to reform the waterfront. That is notwithstanding the fact that they threw $420 million at the issue for a few years in attempts to buy people out of their jobs. They acknowledged, when they embarked on their limited process of reform, that the waterfront was about 50 per cent overmanned.

Instead of taking firm action to deal with that problem, they simply threw money at it and sought to buy people's retirement by offering them golden handshakes. A number of people took those golden handshakes. What happened? Not long after taking those golden handshakes, in many instances they returned to the waterfront as part-time or casual employees. It did not achieve the efficiencies that were required.

Even with the limited reduction in manning levels that were achieved, the real reforms were never achieved. The rorts and problems that are inherent on the waterfront and that have been detailed over many weeks now—such as the nick-offs, the double time and so on—remain. They are the rorts and the problems that this government is intent on dealing with and finding a solution to so that we have world's best practice on the Australian waterfront. That is absolutely required by this country because of its dependence on export earnings as a major generator of the nation's and the community's wealth. We need to proceed with that issue.

That is where the previous government failed. They did not give Australian industry—and all of the workers in all of Australia's industries that are dependent on the waterfront—the benefit of that reform process. Instead what Labor gave employees was high interest rates and high unemployment. It continued to protect the MUA's monopoly situation on our waterfront.

In contrast, the Howard Liberal-National Party government is determined to take those important issues head-on and find solutions to them. That is why we have been prepared to support Patricks. As I said earlier, Patricks was prepared to stand up and say, `Enough is enough. We are going to be part of a waterfront reform process.' They were driven to that by the fact that they were sent bankrupt by the thuggery and inefficiency of the members of the MUA on the Australian waterfront.

The reform is absolutely essential. It is interesting to note that reform is achievable, despite the fact that the MUA says that they are working at their best capacity. They have brought forward bogus reports to say that the crane rates are highly efficient—I think the claimed rate was 19, as published in a study by the MUA a few weeks ago. They say that that is the best we can do in Australia.

It is interesting to note that today the MUA admits that productivity on the Australian waterfront has increased by up to 10 per cent since action was taken by Patricks and others to bring this matter to a head and seek proper reform on the waterfront. It is the old saying: `Nothing concentrates the mind like knowing you are going to be hanged in the morning.' That is exactly what has happened with the MUA. They are now confronted with the reality of their future employment and job security because of the actions they took in the past sending one company broke. P&O is now signing on to the government's reform program. It is signing on to achieving the seven waterfront benchmarks that we have established. The MUA know that the game is up and that unless some improvement is found rapidly their jobs are in jeopardy.

Now that they are back at work we see productivity up by 10 per cent. That productivity improvement must continue. Ten per cent is a start, but it is certainly not enough to achieve the benchmarks that the govern ment has established. That reform process must be maintained and strengthened. We must have an end to the industrial warfare upon which the MUA has embarked which has cost Patricks $56 million and which costs each ship $25,000 a day when it is held up in a port.

In Adelaide last weekend we saw the MUA refuse to allow P&O waterfront employees to load a scrap metal ship bound for the United States because that contract was originally a Patricks contract. Supposedly, Patricks was back in business with their employees returning to work but, because of the industrial action, Patricks had subcontracted that work to P&O and that subcontract remained in force. The MUA refused to allow the P&O waterfront employees to load that ship and were attempting to insist that the reinstated employees of Patricks would load it. Because of the dispute initiated by the MUA, the ship remained idle for several days. As I recollect, in the end a third stevedoring company, Sealand, finished up loading that ship. It hired the Patrick employees on a temporary basis.

That is the sort of nonsense that the MUA carries on with. Even when the dispute was resolved and the opportunity was there for them to return to work, they wanted immediately to overturn plans that had been put in place as a direct consequence of their own earlier industrial action. There is clearly an attitude in the MUA that they are not willing to compromise and not willing to meet the reform process. Their leader has made it very clear, on a number of occasions, that although they want to go back to work with Patricks they do not want to embark on any serious achievement of reform.

Again, it is worth noting today that P&O has put up a proposal for there to be no strikes for the next six months on the waterfront. P&O sought an order preventing any industrial action by MUA members at any terminal for the next six months, obviously as a precursor to developing more productive practices on the waterfront. What did MUA secretary John Coombs do? He described that proposal, the fact that there should not be any industrial disputes, as nonsense.

I would have thought after the past few months when many working hours have been lost through industrial disputation—and it was that which in the end forced Patrick to make their workers redundant, the fact that there were some 30-odd days of industrial action by their employees prior to the retrenchment of their workers—that surely the MUA has learnt from this experience. It is time that they accepted the need for waterfront reform, that they accepted the need for greatly improved productivity, that they accepted the need to get rid of all the rorts that have been so exhibited on the waterfront over many years in Australia, so that those industries whose lifeblood is dependent on an efficient waterfront can produce the wealth for this country.

talk.start.para: —I wish to rise again to discuss the role of Mr Peter Scanlon so that all senators can know and understand why it is totally inappropriate for the government to do business with him. This is a man who is at the centre of this argument. Government senators can try to ignore the sorts of people that they, through their government and Peter Reith, the minister for industrial relations, have got into bed with, because that is what they have done. Not a word has come from government senators about their attempts to breach their laws. Senator Chapman liked to talk about the laws of the land. The laws that the government senators voted for over there have put Peter Reith in the dock because that is where Peter Reith will end up. That is where Peter Scanlon will end up again. It is a breach of your government's laws that is going to see the embarrassment and the documents dragged out.

speech.para: Remember, it is Mr Peter Scanlon who had to resign as the chairman of the Victorian TAB when he was facing criminal charges. Mr Peter Scanlon is still under investigation by the National Crime Authority and not surprisingly has not been reappointed to any position within the Victorian government. Despite this, he has been hand-picked by Peter Reith and the coalition government to carry out waterfront reform. I would like to quote from Mr Ken Jarrett's statement to the court in March 1994, which shows clearly the character of Mr Peter Scanlon and why this federal government should have nothing to do with him.

For those on the opposite side of the chamber who do not know who Ken Jarrett is, he was an intimate business associate, one of the key financial people at Elders during the 1980s—John Elliott's right-hand man. Peter Scanlon worked with Ken Jarrett for years. Ken Jarrett speaks with complete authority on Peter Scanlon and the scams, rorts and shams that went on inside Elders, which have been the subject of much debate in this chamber. So Ken Jarrett is a man in a position to talk about Peter Scanlon and the sort of bloke that he is. I start by quoting from paragraph 10, which states:
By the early 1980s Scanlon had become involved with strategy. He played the dominant role in the Elders and Carlton United Brewery merger transactions.
Paragraph 11 states:
At some time after the merger between Henry Jones IXL and Elders, Cowper moved to Monaco with Wiesener—
two of the other principals whose names continually recur when it comes to that Melbourne establishment club of spivs that took over some of the companies—

talk.start.para: —They're all your mates.
—I don't think they are any of our mates, not by any shot, Senator Ferris. Ken Jarrett went on:

speech.para: They both then ceased to be Directors of Henry Jones IXL. Cowper and Wiesener together established a business providing merchant banking and financial services in Monaco. I am aware that they continued to maintain associations with Elliott and Scanlon and, to an extent, with myself and other executives of Elders. They continued to identify opportunities for Elders.
So this is the man who was dealing with Elliott, who was dealing with Peter Scanlon. Paragraph 12 states:

In about June 1984 EXL, through a subsidiary Elders N.V., made an issue in Europe of convertible bonds having a face value of U.S. $160 million. The motivation for the issue was partly a need for EXL to raise capital and partly to enable executives of the company to take up financial interests in the company in a manner which could be self-funded. I believe the scheme to finance executive participation was proposed initially by Bankers Trust. It was attractive to the intended beneficiaries in that it was expected that the bonds would increase in value as EXL prospered and it would enable them to maintain some control over the company.
Paragraph 13 states:

I became involved in discussions relating to the proposal initially with Wiesener and Elliott. By the time that issue was made Elliott, Scanlon, Wiesener, Cowper and Lord were, to my knowledge, aware of the executive participation.

So what you have happening here is a decision by Elders executives, including Ken Jarrett, to set up a hidden transaction where they became the beneficial owners of these bonds which gave them a significant controlling influence at Elders. That would be fine if they wanted to go out and raise the money themselves, but that is not what actually happened.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. What Senator Conroy opposite is saying may well be of interest. I have been listening to him for six minutes or so and we do know that he is preoccupied with matters to do with Elders. Mr Scanlon, I understand—was he a director of Elders at some stage?
—What is the point of order?

—The point of order is that, under Senator Faulkner's general business notice of motion No. 1103 moved by Senator O'Brien, we are talking about Patrick Stevedores. At this stage, Senator Conroy, after six minutes, has failed to relate any of the matters in his speech to the motion before the chair. I do not know whether you can talk about any company, whether you want to talk about Bond Corporation and Brian Burke or Paul Keating and Heypesbury Holdings or Laurie Connell and other Labor Party figures under the guise of any motion about any company. I am not sure whether you can talk about any prime minister—
—Senator Campbell, you really should stick to the point of order. You should not be debating the issue.

—The point of order is this: within the standing orders dealing with relevance, is the senator opposite capable of dealing with any corporate restructuring of any company in Australian history and the involvement of Labor prime ministers and premiers in those, or is he, in some way, supposed to deal with the matter of Patrick Stevedores and particularly the issue of industrial relations that is specifically referred to in Senator Faulkner's notice of motion—that is, the responsibilities of employers to their employees in these matters—or can you talk about any corporate affairs matter that you want to if the name of a company is mentioned?
—Senator Conroy, you have to move closer to the subject under discussion. You have a very long introduction.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. This motion is about asset stripping. It goes to the character of the people involved in running Patricks. What I am detailing is previous activities of the principals of Patricks and showing how they have not just done what they did to Patricks once, but they have done it before. They have form and they have a consistent record in this. The testimony that I am putting into the Senate's record today is about how asset stripping relates to what they learnt; what Scanlon learnt about asset stripping in his previous activities.

—Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, I raise the same point of order. I think you upheld my previous point of order and I ask you to do so again: when debating a motion that deals with Patrick Stevedores and employer-employee relationships, a senator does not have the right to talk about the asset stripping in Bell Corporation that took place under the eyes of Paul Keating or Bond Corporation, or indeed anything to do with Elders IXL. I ask you to uphold my point of order.

—Senator Campbell, resume your seat. Senator Conroy, stick to the motion that is before the chair which relates to the corporate restructur ing and asset stripping of Patrick Stevedores's labour hire companies.
—Thank you. I will, as you suggest, guide my remarks to the asset stripping question. As I was saying, paragraph 13 states:

speech.para: I—
referring to Ken Jarrett—
became involved in discussions relating to the proposal initially with Wiesener and Elliott. By the time that issue was made Elliott, Scanlon, Wiesener, Cowper and Lord—

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Mr Jarrett has nothing to do with Patrick Stevedores as far as I understand. The senator opposite has entirely ignored your last ruling. I would ask you to bring him to order once again. He just cannot get it through his thick skull.
—Stick to the motion before the chair, Senator Conroy.
—On the point of order: the principal of asset stripping was Peter Scanlon, not Alan Bond, not Brian Burke, not any of those other people. This is a motion to do with the behaviour—
—Are you debating the issue?
—No. You spoke on a point of order longer than I have spoken so far.

speech.para: Senator Ian Campbell interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Campbell, be quiet.
—This is about the principal involved in the asset stripping, Mr Peter Scanlon. This is directly relevant to the behaviour of Mr Peter Scanlon.
—Senator Conroy, I am ruling that you are straying from the motion before the chair. You either accept my ruling or I will move to the next speaker.

—I was speaking to the point of order. As I said, I will guide my remarks to the motion. If I am ever given more than one minute before being interjected upon, I might be able to start to draw my remarks together. But, with the guidance of the chair, I am sure I will get there. Mr Jarrett goes on to say about Mr Scanlon, Mr Scanlon being the principal asset stripper of Patricks:

speech.para: Of the U.S. $160 million issue a sizeable parcel of (to the best of my recollection) around U.S. $105 million, was taken up by or on behalf of executives in EXL or associates of these executives.
That is Mr Peter Scanlon.

talk.start.para: —You are testing my patience, Senator Conroy. The motion relates to Patrick Stevedores.
—He's got no other notes.
—I can talk about Scanlon and all the rest of your Liberal spivvy mates till the cows come home.
—Are they in your branch?
—All your spivvy mates—
—Address your remarks through the chair, Senator Conroy.
—Ask her to stop interjecting then.
—Have you finished speaking?
—I am on my feet. She is interjecting and you are calling me to order.
—I am directing you to direct your speech through the chair. Neglect the interjections from the other side of the chamber. I will deal with those, not you.

—Thank you. As I said, this goes to the heart of Peter Scanlon's asset stripping at Patricks—I am referring to where he learnt how to do it. Part of what has happened in Elders with Ken Jarrett and what Ken Jarrett has revealed on the public record is absolutely integral to the behaviour, the conduct and the asset stripping of Patricks. As I said, if government senators do not continue to interject, I will start to try to draw it together.

speech.para: Mr Jarrett points out that Wiesener organised the structure of the placements so that the fact of executive participation could be concealed. He continued:
I do not presently have access to much of the relevant documentation. However, I am aware that the funding was provided by Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank, Bankers Trust and Credit Agricole.

Bankers Trust—now there is a coincidence. Who was the chief executive of Bankers Trust? No prizes for guessing. It was Chris Corrigan. Here is a scam set up by Scanlon and administered by Corrigan. But back to Mr Jarrett's testimony for a moment:
I believe that I was told this by Wiesener. Elders entered into an interest rate swap arrangement with Bankers Trust—

talk.start.para: —Senator Conroy, for the very last time, deal with the matter of Patrick Stevedores, not the past history of Elders IXL, otherwise I will call another speaker. That is your last warning.
