Meanwhile, the new jobs network is putting $147.6 million back into the government's pocket while it abrogates its responsibility for dealing with unemployment.

Propping up programs such as work for the dole is a tactical manoeuvre by the government to shift the parameters of the problem from unemployment as a social and economic phenomenon to the unemployed as individuals. The general catchcry is: if you are unemployed, it's your own fault and you should pay. It even goes in the song: `You've got to look for the hero inside yourself'. It plays on and promotes the imagery of the dole bludger in a deeply insidious way.

The Treasurer has also sought to play on the One Nation style prejudices against immigrants. By flexing their muscles and pumping money into tightening border controls, they promote the image of the mischievous illegal immigrant, attempting to unfairly dip into the Australian honey pot.

Now the Treasurer claims that Australia has options; options to distribute benefits in the future. He strongly hinted that a GST will pay for income tax cuts. These hints, that deliberately antagonise the welfare lobby, are an attempt to derail a constructive and positive debate on tax reform. Moreover, this simplistic notion of tax reform has very clear winners and losers. Those who pay more income tax will reap the greatest benefits. The way in which personal income tax is determined means that, even if every marginal tax rate is diminished, high income earners will get the biggest windfall. They will get a tax break at every marginal rate.

It is widely understood that a GST disproportionately affects low income earners. It is clear to see who Mr Costello is lining up to get the rewards of all the hard yards. It is not the people who have borne the brunt of the burdens; it is those who have already had many of the advantages society has to offer. The government is driving a deep wedge between the prosperous and those struggling to make a reasonable life for themselves and their families. This budget amplifies that wedge.

The government, in the last two budgets, has placed a priority on debt reduction through a cutback in public sector outlays. The aim and focus has been primarily on a nice, fat bottom line. The government boasts about moving towards surplus and tightening our belts. The government claims that these priorities are the so-called `fundamentals' of the economy, and once we get those fundamentals under control, there can only be prosperity for everyone.

Australians are crying out for the government to understand the economy in the context of the `fundamentals' of society, the `fundamentals' of the Australian ethos—fundamental concepts such as caring, tolerance, quality of life and a fair go for all Australians. This means 100 per cent of Australians; not just the prosperous or corporate Australians, but indigenous Australians, Australians living in poverty—mind you, over 30 per cent are living below or just above the poverty line—rural Australians, disabled Australians, elderly Australians, young Australians and sick Australians.

The result of previous cutbacks has been devastating for the most disadvantaged part of Australian society. The results are becoming more and more obvious. In a relentless pursuit of efficiency, a society of the overworked and unemployed is emerging. Welfare providers on the ground are seeing a massive increase in the need for their services. Just ask them. Welfare providers have seen people come through their doors who have never had to ask for help before. Things have got to such a desperate state, however, that people have had to lower their dignity and actively appeal for help because they just cannot make ends meet.

In 1998, we have a growing working poor in Australia. Despite all the evidence on the ground, the government has not heard the cries of the Australian people. The government has closed their eyes to the impact of their relentless pursuit of debt retirement. They have been conveniently mesmerised by that nice fat bottom line. Despite any realities in Australian society, despite the blow out in the current account deficit and despite the falling exchange rate, they continue to claim that prosperity will come. Just you wait and see.

Not only does the government's approach produce social problems, but the economic basis is, to say the least, questionable. In economic terms, does Mr Costello really deserve a pat on the back for the budget surplus? Is he justified in expecting the surplus to expand? The government is happy to take the accolades for the surplus and to wear the badge of economic responsibility, but is this truly an economically responsible strategy?

As pointed out by Professor Quiggin in the Australian Financial Review today, this fiscal strategy is highly questionable. The government fails to recognise that Telstra is a major contributor to public savings. Telstra uses retained earnings to finance investment and produces over $1 billion in retained earnings every year. This is obviously a huge contribution to public sector savings and it does not show up in the budget papers. Quiggin also notes that Treasury fails to take into account the fact that the government does not claim franking credits. Private shareholders, however, are sure to claim these credits. Quiggin estimates that this will be a cost to revenue of $600 million. So the projected $700 million gained in interest savings by 2001-2002 is looking rather irresponsible in light of the $1 billion in retained earnings and the $600 million lost through franking credits.

Surplus? The longevity of the surplus is a sceptical proposition. The government took bows for the recovery of the `$10 billion Labour deficit', despite the fact that nearly half was due to bracket creep—a thing that they decried Labor for on a number of occasions. Similarly, the government is taking the bows for surplus projections despite the fact that Treasury provided the government with a $5.5 billion windfall by adjusting the parameters on which the budget is based. How nice to be able to spend some of this handy windfall while being able to present an ever increasing surplus estimate for the coming years.

Many commentators, including John Hewson, have pointed out that the surplus forward estimates should be taken with a truckload of salt. The impact of the Asian crisis has been underestimated, and the surplus projections have been bolstered by unrealistic spending projections and artificial ly low spending projections. What we should be doing is looking at structuring the Australian economy to better weather the external storms. Bottom lines provide no real projections. If we have in this country a situation where every time there is an increased consumer confidence we have a blow-out in imports, somebody should be asking questions.

The government's suggestion that economic benefits will flow from pushing the budget to surplus is another dubious proposition. This is certainly not the case in relation to the current account deficit. The coalition's policies and claims are based on the concept of the `twin deficit theory' pushed by the International Monetary Fund. This theory is based on a link between budget deficits and surpluses and the current account deficit or surplus. As a result, the IMF continually pushes free market style structural adjustment policies—they pull it out of the drawer and they give it to every country they go into—labour market reform and substantial cuts to government spending as the best means of addressing problems such as large current account deficits.

The coalition has been a great fan of IMF style policies. Indeed, the Prime Minister was reverberating advice coming from the IMF's Mr Camdessus on page 2 of the Australian on Friday, 8 May 1998, by claiming that our recent current account blow-out meant that tight fiscal policy was needed. The idea of the twin deficit theory has never been born out in practice. This is overwhelmingly illustrated by the latest current account figures. Despite moves towards budget surplus over the last two years, our current account deficit is at its highest level ever. If anything, it appears that the more the current account deficit blows out, the more the Reserve Bank is able to produce more favourable dividends, which in turn makes the budget easier to balance.

The current account deficit, which reflects the state of the national economy, deserves serious attention. A good current account deficit can give leeway to deal with government budget deficits. A bad current account deficit can cause national economic collapse in spite of government surpluses.

The short-term focus of the budget surplus has failed Australia miserably. It has entrenched social, environmental and economic deficit. Socially, it has increased poverty and tension. Environmentally, it has ignored the real damage that is occurring and the reality that future generations will have to pay the mounting environmental debt. Economically, it will be shown to be wanting in the long term. Wipe that smug smile off your face, Mr Costello. Judge the budget truthfully. The Greens will be watching you and looking at the real indicators of Australia's well being on behalf of the forgotten community.
Debate (on motion by Senator Parer) adjourned.

debate.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —This week, probably for the first time in Australian political history, we have seen a consensus reached between the established parties on the need for a balanced budget. This is truly an historic moment of consensus in the debate about the future of our country's finances and the direction of Australia's economic policy. This week on the Face to Face program, Gareth Evans, Labor's shadow finance and treasury spokesman, said that the Labor Party now supports the goal of a surplus, that is, a balanced budget, one which is out of the red and into the black.

speech.para: Mr Evans told Glen Milne on the Face to Face program that he agrees that we should have a balanced budget and, in fact, he claimed that Labor would try to produce a budget surplus. Do not hold your breath though, Mr Evans, that opportunity is years away.

Labor's newest graduate from the Democrats' finishing school, Mrs Kernot, also said over the weekend that a budget surplus was an `appropriate and symbolic goal'. Surely this statement begs the question: from 1990 to 1995 did she let the world's greatest treasurer know of her secret, symbolic goal? It would not appear so, because in May 1992 Mrs Kernot told the Senate that the Democrats did not support `the balanced budget nonsense' being pursued at that time by the coalition in opposition. So we can only conclude that this newly discovered appearance of responsibility has been collected on her way across to Mr Evans's office, from where she faxed her resignation to Democrat party headquarters. So now, former Senator Kernot and former Senator Evans have yet another new compact. But, as usual, no praise from her for this government's sensational budget surplus delivered by our Treasurer just two days ago.

Appropriate and symbolic—that is how Labor now describes the notion of a balanced budget. Of course, in the nineties, Labor often said they would have liked to have brought in a balanced budget. But, instead, they created the recession we had to have and the deficits just grew and grew like Topsy, until thousands of people woke up and gave them the sack. Even so, they left all of us with a disgraceful $10.3 billion deficit.

Meanwhile, back in the Democrats' newly reconstructed post-Kernot cottage, they also seem to be trying to improve their image and, goodness knows, they need to. Senator Meg Lees released the party's pre-budget submission last week, outlining her views and the party's views on budget policy—surely a new experience for the Democrats. She has elaborated on them in here tonight, and guess what? The Australian Democrats now also believe that, and I quote:
There is room for a modestly more expansive fiscal policy that delivers a balanced Budget and simultaneously provides a boost to the economy.

Fancy that! The budget proposals of the Democrats also represent a balancing act and also advocate a surplus as a desirable economic goal, although one a lot more modest than the one we produced just two days ago.

Despite the many shortcomings of the Democrats pre-budget submission, it is significant to take note of one important concession. That is, that the Democrats share our support for the government's determination to make a balanced budget a permanent part of Australia's economic policy making environment. This is a very commendable objective from the cottage of the Democrats. This consensus between the established parties about the desirability of a balanced budget represents a historic pact in Australian politics which should not be overlooked. It is a commendable objective.

With this newly discovered consensus, the policy debate can now move steadily onwards. We have been warning that Australia can no longer live beyond its means with the profligate tax and spending policies of the former government. Isn't it now refeshing, and perhaps a little surprising, to find that both other established parties now agree? However, fundamental differences still remain, of course, especially in terms of our capacity to deliver on these economic policies. The Democrats' pronouncements reveal that they still fail to appreciate that it is the very budget surplus which is proving to be our key safeguard against the financial chaos now sweeping the Asian region.

The surplus is part of Australia's very precious insurance policy. `She'll be right, mate' may be part of the Australian idiom but it should not be part of any responsible political party. Never again should a political party in government be allowed to accumulate the massive debt that lay under the mat on 3 March 1996—never again. There should be no debt, no burden for our children, no crippling interest rate bills and, especially, no Beazley bankcard.

talk.start.para: —Monday 4 May 1998 was a defining day for the Australian labour movement. The High Court of Australia in a six to one decision decided that the sacked employees of Patrick Stevedores should be immediately reinstated. Despite the best efforts of the `spin merchants' for Minister Reith, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), and Patrick, the High Court judgment was an unambiguous statement on the question of the unfair sacking of the unionised work force. The fact that the coalition government is trying every conceivable stunt and scam to ensure that the Patrick labour hire companies fall over is a testimony to how deep a hole they have dug for themselves in this debacle.

speech.para: On the same day, over 15,000 unionists took to the streets of Brisbane in the largest Labour Day march since the 1930s. The large turnout signalled the level of anti-Howard government feeling for the way it has handled the maritime dispute. This ill will is generated by the deceit of Dubai, the pack mentality of dogs and security guards displacing people from their workplace, and the initial delight with which this government greeted the midnight sacking of an entire unionised work force.

Regardless of any questions about waterfront reform, Australians do not like to see this confrontation forced upon other Australians. This imagery will linger in their thoughts for quite a while, and people have only naturally been asking themselves the question, `Is my job safe?'

Over the past few weeks we have heard conflicting stories from the Prime Minister, Minister Reith, Dr Webster, Mr Corrigan, and former Fynwest owner, Mike Wells, and there is no doubt it is time the Australian public was afforded a factual account of the events of the past 12 to 18 months. It is time for a full independent inquiry, although I would be quite happy to see Minister Reith squirm under questioning from Jennifer Byrne and Kerry O'Brien on the 7.30 Report a couple more times before the full facts become known.

I would like to focus on a Queensland aspect of the waterfront dispute. Queensland, you will remember, is the state where the Premier, Deputy Premier and industrial relations minister were begging the NFF to set up their operation before a state election. The Borbidge government was desperate to escalate the dispute to extract any ounce of political advantage, and Mr Borbidge demanded that his police commissioner get tough with peaceful picket line protesters. Mr Borbidge and his industrial relations minister, Mr Santoro, taunted and antagonised the wharf workers in a divisive attempt to seek an election trigger.

Like their federal colleagues, they have completely misread the central issue for the public—job security concerns. Like their federal colleagues, they have shown that the key feature of this dispute never has been waterfront reform; it has always been about smashing the Maritime Union of Australia and, as a result, commencing the dismantling of the Australian union movement. The stevedore, Sea-Land Australia, which has a good relationship with the MUA and defends the productivity of its workers, has also shown that this dispute is not about waterfront reform.

The events we have witnessed in relation to the waterfront dispute represent the most serious effort in nearly a century by the forces of the conservative establishment to do a hatchet job on the Australian labour movement. These forces—manifested as Prime Minister Howard, Minister Reith, the NFF and myriad unknown business backers—have failed legally, economically and socially to break the resolve of the MUA.

The coalition, as the political lap dogs of the conservative elites, have been prepared to introduce a sense of anarchy and zealotry into Australian society in an attempt to pursue their ideological vendetta against unionised workplaces. In the best traditions of coalition governments, they have attempted to stir up old hatreds in Australian society. Wharfies have been accused of disloyalty to Australia in wartime, working only 14 hour weeks, and being responsible for all the failings of the Australian economy. Regrettably, all this hysteria has done nothing for national cohesion and reconciliation.

In the process, the coalition has made a mockery of its own legislation. What their actions are saying is that it is not an issue for them to defy the dismissal and freedom of association provisions of the Workplace Relations Act, but that it is essential that the MUA and the ACTU follow to the letter the secondary boycott provisions of the act.

What this government induced confrontation has also displayed is that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is the best forum in which to settle workplace disputes. However, the coalition's ideological obsession to strip the commission of its authority and Mr Corrigan perjuring himself at a commission hearing earlier this year indicate the low esteem conservatives in Australia have for this institution.

The NFF contribution to this dispute and the actions, including the inactions, of its affiliates and individual members should be condemned in the strongest possible terms. It was not too long ago that the farmers of Australia enjoyed a considerable degree of goodwill from the rest of the community. Due to the soul destroying and financially crippling effects of drought, Australians got behind primary producers and supported them in their tough times. As many people would appreciate, the MUA was one of the most generous donors to farmers. Now we see the peak farm representative organisation, the NFF, telling us about multimillion dollar hidden fighting funds and their desire to be a leading stevedore enterprise. All Australians, not just waterside workers, would be entitled to ask whether they have been conned in the past for feeling sympathy for the farm sector. The actions of the NFF have, by association, put under the microscope the activities of the rural sector. If this sector is serious about seeking reform on Australia's docks, let it come into the debate with clean hands. Let it address some of the anti-competitive, highly protectionist practices within its own industry.

I read an excellent article in last Saturday's Courier-Mail called `Is It Time For Rural Reform, Too?' by award winning journalist, Tony Koch. He questioned the figures which suggest a majority of farmers are on low or negative incomes and whether the average farm indebtedness of $240,000 should be a message to producers and government that perhaps it is time for these people to leave the land. Mr Koch suggested that unproductive farming practices did not deserve to receive an array of state and federal government funding, which includes subsidies for fertilisers, water, diesel, power and freight, amongst a raft of other areas.

He suggested that farming in geographically unsuitable areas and supporting farmers simply to maintain a family generational connection with the land are no longer acceptable and that governments should review their subsidies in these instances. The article also revealed the inefficiencies and the potential rorts in the administration of various producer organisations. It was revealed that, of the 359 statutory authorities in Queensland, 121 related to primary production. Surely this unwieldy form of administration is in need of reform?

The budget revealed that the Howard government is keen to extend and entrench these unproductive practices even further within the rural sector. The announcement of a tax rebate of up to 34 per cent for producers to maintain their own land, which will be potentially available to 70 per cent of farmers, will do nothing for genuine farm reform. The initiative is designed to appease the core constituency of the National Party who have been threatening to change to One Nation in their droves. Like so many of the entrenched subsidies to the farm sector, they are draped with a political pandering emphasis. In calling for reform on the waterfront, the rural sector is putting its own industry under scrutiny, and it needs to appreciate this point when it allows its peak industry body to lead the charge against the MUA.

Finally, I would like to defend the reputation of workers on Brisbane's wharves. These people have been denigrated by both their Prime Minister and their Premier as `not workers but wharfies'. An article in an edition of last month's Business Queensland, hardly a publication known for its sympathy to employees, outlined that, of the major container ports in Australia, the Port of Brisbane has probably the least room for a large improvement in crane rates. It stated that Brisbane, like Fremantle, is often a port which is either a first or last port of call. This means that, when loading and unloading containers, crane operators usually have to unload other containers to gain access to the ones they really want to unload. The article also highlighted the folly of making comparisons between Brisbane and the world leader, Singapore. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Tonight I take the opportunity to open up for public debate within the tax reform environment the need for a limited carry back of tax losses. Currently, Australia enjoys a carry forward of tax losses, but such an environment does not help all companies, particularly those that face the insolvency or bankruptcy of a major client and a situation where they have paid tax on an accrual basis and have paid their income tax on that. The result is generally difficulty for the business and a problem for continued employment.

speech.para: Prior to that I wish to spend a moment or two on tax reform generally. As we all know, the tax system was designed in the 1930s. The 1936 income tax act had only 120 pages. It now has some 3,300 or more. In fact, over the last seven years it has doubled in size. Therefore, few would disagree that the existing system is inefficient, uncompetitive, inequitable, high-cost compliant and increasingly complex. Both the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) have stated that comprehensive tax reform is now a matter of urgency, widely sought and widely desired.

The objectives that the government has set for the reform of the tax system are to provide incentives to work, save and invest and to boost international competitiveness, thus promoting job creation and leading to improved living standards. As we enter the new millennium, it is imperative that Australia go forth with full vigour in order to maximise our potential and to regain our place on the world stage.

Inheriting an underlying budget deficit of $10.3 billion was a major setback and a major shock for the coalition on winning government. I must say that it has taken strong fiscal management in order to fill that black hole left by Messrs Keating and Beazley. There have been no increased taxes, just careful restraint of outlays, to return Australia's macro-economic fundamentals to a sound footing. That has been particularly important given the Asian meltdown.

Tax reform, however, remains the greatest piece of unfinished business on the economic agenda. Business, operating in highly contested domestic and global markets, needs little convincing of the benefits of tax reform. The current system is imposing costs which can no longer be afforded. Small business and larger companies have separate as well as common concerns for reform. Governments at all levels are seeing their revenue bases gradually eroded by structural change in the economy and are having to apply complex, inefficient and unpopular bandaid measures in response. The Howard government, through tax reform, will achieve better economic and social outcomes, higher living standards, strengthened families and real jobs.

On 13 August, the Prime Minister announced the formation of an interdepartmental task force to report to government on options for reform. The broad guidelines given to the tax consultative task force were: there should be no increase in the overall tax burden; there should be major reductions in personal income tax, especially for families; a broad-based indirect tax should be considered to replace some or all of the existing indirect taxes; compensation for those deserving of special consideration must be part of the package; and a reform of government and state financial relations must be addressed.

From these guidelines it is clear that the government's present thinking involves comprehensive reform of both direct and indirect taxes. But I remind the Senate that tax reform must be more than providing tax savings or tax cuts to individuals or shareholders. The reform must assist business to ensure that cost compliance is at a minimum and enable it to take advantage of competitive environments in both domestic and international markets. Many individuals and representatives of the community have taken up the government's offer to present their views on how best to improve the current system. There have been over 500 submissions to the committee. This has been an important and constructive process which continues.

There is a need to support and enhance the competitiveness of Australian industry in both the domestic and export markets. Many countries have provisions which allow losses to be offset against income from other periods. Carry forward of losses, where losses can be written off against future years profits, is provided for in most countries. Carry back—the concept that I am encouraging people to examine tonight—is where current losses can be written off against past years profits. This measure is provided for in a number of OECD countries and it has a number of advantages for companies and employment.

Carry back involves a procedure of amended assessments and refunds. The value of any carry forward or carry back of losses will depend on a variety of factors affecting the business of a company. A company just commencing operations will be unable to use any carry back, while a company ceasing operations will be unable to use any carry forward. Of the OECD countries studied, only Australia and New Zealand do not allow any carry back. The carry back is limited to three years in Canada and the UK, two years in the US and Germany and only one year in Japan.

Because of our dividend imputations, which complicates the situation, what I am advocating for Australia is just a one-year carry back. But in Canada, the US and Japan, the taxpayers have a choice of carrying the loss forward, back or using a combination. In Germany, unused losses are automatically carried back across the two preceding years, with any excess loss being carried forward. The carry back of losses in Germany is limited to DM10 million.

As well as carry back, Germany and the UK allow an indefinite carry forward; however, in the UK the carry forward and deduction of losses is allowed only against income from the same trade as a loss. Carry forwards are indefinite in Australia, the UK, Germany and New Zealand. They are limited to 20 years in the US, seven years in Canada and five years in Japan.

So in comparison with the OECD group, the current Australian treatment of losses suffers because there are no provisions for actual carry back. It is difficult to allow the carry back of losses under a full imputation system such as that in Australia. However, allowing the carry back of losses for one year would be practical, would minimise the loss of revenue in consequence of having given credit to individual shareholders, and would bring Australia into line with the intent of carry back provisions of other OECD countries and our major trading partners.

The United Kingdom treatment of trading losses and their offset against profits of preceding periods is an excellent example to examine. For current accounting periods after 31 March, the end of the UK financial year, a company's trading losses can, to the extent to which they cannot be used against the current period's profits, also be carried back against profits arising from the previous 36 months, with any necessary apportionment of the results of a previous accounting period being made to effect this.

A company in the UK must make its claim for relief within two years of the end of the accounting period in which it made its loss, with a statutory power in respect of the general three-year carry back to increase the limit where appropriate. Relief is given against profits of a later accounting period before those of an earlier accounting period.

The present system in Australia prejudices those businesses receiving very large payments in one year, with considerably smaller payments in the next, with a consequent higher tax payment. A case could well be where a subcontractor, with a contract spanning two years, receives a very large progress payment in one financial year and, because of a profit circumstance, is subject to a higher than normal bill for taxation. Because of cash flow requirements in order to complete the contract, the subcontractor is forced to borrow funds in order to settle his commitments to the tax office. After borrowing from a financial institution and providing the necessary security, the subcontractor then submits the final account for work carried out under the two-year contract. However, the contractor is unable to pay because the contractor has declared insolvency. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Labor Party: Selection of Candidates

talk.start.para: —Senators may recall that yesterday, during the matters of public interest debate, I raised the quite disgraceful situation in Townsville where the ALP has been rigging the vote in their preselections, which resulted yesterday in the then candidate for the state electorate of Thuring owa being summonsed in respect of 54 criminal charges of uttering and forging which are being prosecuted against her.

speech.para: Upon the serving of those summonses, the Labor Party dismissed her as the candidate and brought back the existing member who, some time previously, had announced that he was too old and that it was time to give it away and let a younger person have a go. Suddenly, he has been thrust back into the limelight; he is standing again in the forlorn hope that he might retain the seat.

In the unlikely event that he does retain the seat, he would be there only as a caretaker; he has no interest whatsoever in remaining in the state parliament, knowing that he would be in opposition yet again. That would result in a by-election at very great expense to the Queensland taxpayers, and it would mean that the people of Thuringowa would have a lame duck member who was not interested in representing them. But I do not think that is going to happen, because it is unlikely that Mr McElligott will win the seat. I am quite confident that the Liberal candidate, David Moore, who is a young person—the sort of person that Mr McElligott, the current Labor member, indicated should take over in that seat—will win and give the electors of Thuringowa the sort of representation they deserve.

I was surprised at the fact that people do listen to the parliamentary and news network. Following my speech there were quite a number of calls to my office from people who, like me, were sickened by the evidence of vote rigging by the ALP in the state preselection contest in Townsville—a practice which seems to be fairly widespread in the ALP. I quoted yesterday some evidence from Victoria and New South Wales, and indicated that this malaise, this disease, in those states has now spread to North Queensland.

It was bad enough that Ms Ehrmann was summonsed on 54 counts of forging and uttering and was dismissed by the Labor Party—although, just a couple of days before that, the state leader of the Labor Party in Queensland, Mr Beattie, had been expressing great confidence in this candidate, and had even agreed to come to Townsville to open her campaign office this Saturday. Of course, Mr Beattie is too weak and too ineffectual to be able to control some of the shenanigans and goings-on within the Labor Party in Townsville.

That was bad enough, but we find out today that, as a result of all that preselection vote rigging by the ALP in the Townsville area, a Townsville City Council alderman, Councillor Shane Foster, has also been charged as part of that racket. He has been charged with 32 counts of forging and uttering. I emphasise that he has only been charged; he is, of course, not guilty until the court proceeds with those matters.

For those of us who live in the Townsville area, it is something that has been expected for a long time, because the preselections up there have been particularly bitter. It has now happened that the successful candidate, who some say won as a result of that vote rigging, has now been forced to stand aside.

Those sorts of rumours have been going around as well in the state electorate of Townsville, where the former mayor, Mike Reynolds, defeated the current mayor, Tony Mooney, for preselection for that state seat. In fact, a report in the Townsville Bulletin this morning said:
Mike Reynolds, an Ehrman—
and Ehrman was the candidate who had been forced to resign after receiving those summonses—
pre-selection ally and candidate for Townsville, reacted angrily when asked yesterday whether he had been summonsed.

Again, he says he has not, but you get the flavour of what is happening from the article on the front page of the Townsville Bulletin . The people of Townsville wait to see whether, in addition to the candidate for Thuringowa, a city council alderman, other ALP candidates may be caught up in this vote-rigging, fraudulent, criminal exercise. I wanted to go on at greater length on this—

talk.start.para: —Order! I draw it to your attention that you are sailing very close to the wind. I urge a caution about what you say about these matters which are presumably about to come before the court.

—Thank you. I do not need to comment further on that. I was intending to go on at greater length to explain this, but I understand that my colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald—a National Party senator for New South Wales—wants to speak for a few minutes on the adjournment, so I have agreed to curtail my speech. I understand that he wishes to pay tribute to the recently deceased mayor of the town of Casino in northern New South Wales, Mr Senthil Vasan, a man whom I knew very well. In closing my speech, I indicate that I would like to associate myself with the comments that Senator Sandy Macdonald will make about the former mayor of Casino.

—I wish to take a moment tonight, with some sadness, to pay tribute to the late Senthil Vasan who was the mayor of Casino. I know that Senator Ian Macdonald had been to Casino a number of times and also knew Dr Vasan quite well. As members of the Senate will be aware, Dr Vasan was tragically killed in a plane accident late last week. His passing is a great loss to his family, his friends, the people of Casino and to the north coast of New South Wales generally.

speech.para: Dr Vasan was born in Malaysia 62 years ago and arrived in Casino in 1977 with his wife Vicki and two sons. He immediately became involved in the local community and, during his 21 years as a doctor in general practice in Casino, he was also an active member of Rotary, a visiting medical officer at Casino Hospital, and a member of the aero club.

Dr Vasan entered local government and he was both committed and effective. In 1991, Dr Vasan was elected mayor of Casino. At that time he said, `Casino has been good to me', and he repaid Casino by being good to it. The general manager of the Casino council, Mr Ross Schipp, said:
He was a visionary. A person able to appreciate the bigger picture, something which can be difficult in local government.

Dr Vasan also sat on the Northern Rivers Regional Development Board, was president of the Northern Rivers Regional Organisation of Councils, a past president of the Country Mayors Association and a member of the Premier's Taskforce on Regional Development.

As the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer, said at the funeral, Dr Vasan was a truly outstanding citizen. From my personal contacts with him I know that he was someone who got the most out of life. He was devoted to his family and to his many friends. He was involved in everything. Perhaps most importantly, his energy, initiative and hard work had won him the respect of many people in his new country.

He was a charming and interesting companion and he had a certain mysticism about him that was very much a product of his heritage. His close friend and the deputy mayor of Casino, Councillor Mulherin, told the Northern Star newspaper:
Council will carry on because we have to, but we are going to miss Senthil like mad.
I express my deepest sympathy to his wife and sons, who have lost a loving and caring husband and father.

On another matter, I cannot let the opportunity pass without making some comments about the contribution of Senator Gibbs tonight. I do not know what stone Senator Gibbs has been under. She comes in here and reads into Hansard her clapped-out left-wing rhetoric concerning the MUA and the current waterfront dispute. It is a mockery of good reason for Senator Gibbs to defend the MUA and, in a subsequent breath, to criticise Australian farmers.

The comments of my `good friend' Lindsay Tanner are really telling. He is reputed to have said, `It is impossible for us in the ALP to defend the indefensible.' Senator Gibbs's comments breach the Hobart resolution of the ALP conference held in January or early February to open up the waterfront. There is a history of rorts and intimidation. The MUA is not a friend of the farmers: it never has been and it never will be.

In the brief time that I have, I would like to go back to some of the reasons for the reform efforts and note the role that the Australian farmers have played in this area of industrial relations reform. Waterfront reform will boost jobs and exports for all Australians, and this is especially true for primary producers, country people and rural people generally.

With the live sheep dispute in 1979, which was a perfectly bloody-minded effort by the MUA to prevent the export of live sheep to the Middle East, the birth of the NFF was assured. It was a great win for commonsense. Live sheep were exported then and they are still being exported.

Next, in the late 1980s were the changes to bulk handling of wheat on the waterfront after an enormous amount of capital investment which ensured world's best practice. These bulk handling terminals are now substantially operated without union membership—and certainly not by MUA membership.

In 1982, the NFF took on the AWU over the wide-combs dispute in the shearing industry. Here, if ever there was an example of a union being ignorant and bloody-minded, this was the AWU. The AWU destroyed their membership and deserved to do so.

They attempted to stop probably the hardest working people in the country—shearers who get paid piece rates only for what they actually do—not like the MUA who are paid $73,000 a year for meter reading. The AWU tried to stop these people using a bit of equipment that made their job easier and more productive, and ensured them an income which they would not have had if they had continued to work with the smaller combs. It was no wonder that the Australian shearing industry gave the two-fingered salute to the AWU. They left the union membership and have never returned.

In 1985, of course, we had Mudginberri where, again, a union tried to prevent a legitimate operation of an abattoir in the Northern Territory. The NFF was instrumental in making the job of the meat workers in volved in that dispute absolutely impossible for them to survive.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 23 March 1998:

question.para: With reference to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 March 1998, which reported the Minister as saying that parents migrating to Australia as part of family reunion programs come disproportionately from countries which do not have social security systems: (a) can a detailed breakdown be provided of the countries of origin of the migrants who were issued parent visas in the financial years of 1995-96, 1996-97 and to date in 1997-98; and (b) can a breakdown be provided of these countries of origin which do not have social security systems.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) Table 1 below provides a detailed breakdown of the countries of origin (by country of birth) of the migrants who were issued subclass 103 and 804 parent visas for the financial years 1995-96 through to 30 March 1998.

A breakdown has only been provided with respect to countries which represent 1 percent or more of the total number of parent visa grants from 1995-96 to 30 March 1998. Of the 17,350 parent visas issued over the period, 14,643 or 84.5 percent came from these countries. The remaining 2,707 visas were distributed across a further 89 countries.

(b) Of the 18 major source countries, only the United Kingdom has so far been assessed by the Department of Social Security as having a social security system broadly comparable to Australia's (that is, being able to provide a reciprocal level of coverage of age or other pensions for Australians who move to those countries).
